Award.AwardTitle: CRISP Type 1/Collaborative Research: Computable Market and System Equilibrium Models for Coupled Infrastructures

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This interdisciplinary research will develop computational tools and public data sets to enable the joint modeling of interdependent energy infrastructures. The work is motivated by increasing interdependencies between the U.S. electric power and natural gas infrastructures. These interdependencies arise from the dual, increasing roles of natural gas as a base-load resource (replacing coal-fired power plants retiring for economic or environmental reasons) and a balancing resource (to smooth fluctuations in variable renewable energy generation). While natural gas brings environmental benefits over coal, the increased coupling between electricity and gas systems and markets have been difficult to model with existing tools. This research program will develop tractable computational tools and supporting data sets to enable analysis of the operational or economic risks associated with this increasing interdependence and to articulate the economic and social value from increased coordination in system planning, operations and clearing of markets. The research will be beneficial to the energy systems and policy research communities through the development and dissemination of analytical tools, and will help to inform evolving U.S. policy on coordination between energy infrastructures, including electric power and natural gas. This effort will involve an integrated and interdisciplinary collaboration between experts in energy economics, computer science and optimization that will enrich not only the research community but also the education of energy systems scholars from multiple fields.

The research team will create a framework for computable market and system equilibrium models that: capture non-linear aspects of AC power systems and the Weymouth gas flow equations; accurately represent the market institutions in electricity and natural gas that lead to price formation; and capture the cyclic dependence between price formation in spot natural gas markets and the price calculations in spot electricity markets. This framework will embed a market equilibrium model for natural gas within an optimization framework for the joint planning of natural gas and electric power systems. The approach will be implemented on a model of the U.S. northeastern power grid and natural gas pipeline system that is drawn from publicly-available information. The awarded research will demonstrate that this framework can produce sensible outcomes with acceptable computational performance, illustrate the framework on a series of test systems including the U.S. northeast test system, and demonstrate the value of integrated infrastructure planning for natural gas and electric power systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As the power grid in the United States rapidly transitions to the use of natural gas instead of coal as a major fuel for power generation, grid operators, planners and the broader analytical community need improved tools to integrate conditions on the natural gas transmission system into power sector decision-making. This project has developed a suite of open-source modeling tools and simulation test-beds that enable the analysis of market, planning and operational problems for tightly coupled natural gas and electric transmission.

These open-source tools are freely available to the public on an open GitHub site (github.com/lanl-ansi), and provide several functionalities not previously available in the public domain. First, included in the toolkit is a computational gas-grid test system with a realistic topology, assembled entirely from public information. Second, the toolkit develops and implements an optimization-based modeling framework for joint gas-grid planning and steady-state operational analysis. Third, the modeling framework endogenously incorporates market feedbacks from network expansion planning decisions via a sensitivity-based approach.

Through this project, the modeling frameworks developed have been used to analyze several policy-relevant problems related to the increased interdependence between natural gas and power transmission systems.

First, we have assessed the kinds of network planning decisions necessary to mitigate the kinds of market and system impacts that were experienced during the "Polar Vortex" events in the U.S. northeast in the winter of 2014. Using the toolkit developed through this project, we have evaluated optimal network explansion planning and operational decisions under several stress scenarios on the natural gas and electric power networks. Major conclusions from this research include that substantial network investments are needed to mitigate Polar Vortex type stress events in the U.S. northeast, well beyond the network expansions that are currently planned. This suggests that building more infrastructure alone is not necessarily the best way to mitigate network stress conditions in gas-electric systems, and that policy should focus on operational coordination as well as planning.

Second, we have assessed the relative economics of investments in natural gas transmission versus on-site natural gas storage to ensure fuel delivery to gas-fired power plants during periods when both natural gas and power demand are very high. Storage facilities can have lower costs, but are limitied to be used for strategically supply of fuel to specific facilities during periods of high electricity demand. Additional natural gas transmission, on the other hand, is more costly but provides system resilience and mitigates price spikes in congested gas areas on an ongoing basis.

Third, we have developed an operational model for electric power systems that is able to quantify the value of gas market and system information that power grid operators can access when committing and dispatching power plants. We have found that if power grid operators have access to gas network information (market prices and contingency information) before committing power plants to operate, then the frequency of committing power plants to run in unprofitable conditions can be mitigated without the need to introduce new market mechanisms or structural market adjustments in natural gas or electricity.
